nodes.bodyText: It is also a number of macro, not a size ? (size = memory footprint)
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -40,4 +40,8 @@
 // Maximum TTL that can be set using MACROTTL (defaults to 2**62 ms)
 #warpscript.repository.ttl.hard = 
 
+// Number of macros loaded from 'warpscript.repository.directory' to keep in memory
+warpscript.repository.cache.size = 10000
 
+// Size of macro cache for the macros loaded from the classpath
+warpscript.library.cache.size = 10000

nodes.bodyText: Size of caches is measured in number of entries, not actual memory footprint
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -40,4 +40,8 @@

+warpscript.repository.cache.size = 10000

nodes.bodyText: So the second comment should be "Number of macros loaded from the classpath" ?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -40,4 +40,8 @@

nodes.bodyText: Nope, this is the maximum size of the cache, not the number of loaded macros
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -40,4 +40,8 @@
 // Maximum TTL that can be set using MACROTTL (defaults to 2**62 ms)
 #warpscript.repository.ttl.hard = 
 
+// Number of macros loaded from 'warpscript.repository.directory' to keep in memory
+warpscript.repository.cache.size = 10000
 
+// Size of macro cache for the macros loaded from the classpath
+warpscript.library.cache.size = 10000

nodes.bodyText: What about a warning somewhere in the logs to tell user that some macro are not in the cache ?
This warning would be written every time a macro would be loaded once you reach the limit. Setting a Sensision metric with the number of cached macros is probably a better option.
Indeed. With 10000 as default, I doubt this will happen too often.
Why not checking for overflow and not setting expiry if it overflows?
Is there a reason there is a sensision metric for the library and not for the repo?
Same question for logging evicted macros.

Macros which are evicted upon loading of a jar will never get re-added. In the case of the repo, when ondemand is true the macros will get loaded anyway. The ondemand param is true by default so we could log eviction only when it is false.
To avoid having weird comparison results if checking with >
